name: interfaces
brief:
Low-level forward and reverse mode interfaces for tape evaluation

Provides the core differentiation routines that evaluate recorded tapes
in forward mode (computing directional derivatives) and reverse mode
(computing adjoints/gradients). These are the building blocks used by
higher-level drivers like gradient() and hessian().

algorithms.name:
Forward and Reverse Mode Tape Evaluation:

FORWARD MODE (propagate tangents ẋ → ẏ):
- zos_forward(tag, m, n, x, y): Function value only, y = f(x)
- fos_forward(tag, m, n, x, xdot, y, ydot): First derivative, ẏ = f'(x)·ẋ
- hos_forward(tag, m, n, d, x, X, y, Y): Taylor to order d
- fov_forward(tag, m, n, p, x, X, y, Y): p directions simultaneously
- hov_forward(tag, m, n, d, p, x, X, y, Y): p Taylor series to order d

REVERSE MODE (propagate adjoints ȳ → x̄):
- fos_reverse(tag, m, n, ybar, xbar): Gradient, x̄ = f'(x)ᵀ·ȳ
- hos_reverse(tag, m, n, d, ybar, Z): Higher-order adjoints
- hov_reverse(tag, m, n, d, q, U, Z, nz): q adjoints for d-order Taylor
algorithms.math:
Key complexity insight:
For f: ℝⁿ → ℝ (scalar output), one reverse sweep computes ∇f ∈ ℝⁿ.
Cost: ~4× forward evaluation, independent of n.
This is why reverse mode dominates in optimization (gradients are cheap).

Mode naming conventions:
- zos: zero-order-scalar (function value only)
- fos: first-order-scalar (single direction/adjoint)
- hos: higher-order-scalar (Taylor series to order d)
- fov: first-order-vector (p directions simultaneously)
- hov: higher-order-vector (p Taylor series to order d)
- wk: with keep (retain intermediates for subsequent reverse)
- ti: Taylor input (provide input Taylor coefficients)
algorithms.complexity:
Forward: O(d·p·ops) for d-order, p directions.
Reverse: O(d·q·ops) for d-order, q adjoints.
